comments:
Chemistry 101 discusses principles of Chemistry for students with some basic knowledge of Chemistry and Calculus, focusing on understanding chemical reactions at the atomic and molecular level.

Most students found this course to be fairly difficult and hard to understand. The tests were often cited as ambiguous, with "confusing wording." Students found the textbook, Oxtoby's Principles of Modern Chemistry, similarly "cryptic." However, there were students who valued the emphasis on "understanding of concepts rather than simply plugging and chugging numbers."

A number of students complained about Professor Blaisie's "air of superiority" and his difficulty in communicating the complex material. As a result, many students felt more comfortable directing their questions to TAs. While the majority of students connected Blaisie's "rigorous" methods to increased confusion on their part, students who expressed genuine interest in the material found Blaisie to be accessible and engaging.

Due to the complexity of lectures and the difficulty of exams, this class required a lot of work outside of class. This class recommends some background in high school chemistry, and most students enrolled were considering majors in science.

Chemistry 101 discusses principles of chemistry for students with some basic knowledge of chemistry and calculus, focusing on understanding chemical reactions at the atomic and molecular level.

With the exception of a few students who felt "perpetually confused" about the course material, most of the class found the material interesting.   

The class admired Professor Park's "genuine interest" in teaching chemistry to students, emphasizing her availability and willingness to help "even out of her office hours." However, several students also stated that the professor’s "thick accent" made her lectures more confusing.  Those who did not perceive a language barrier tended to find her lectures engaging, especially her demonstrations.

Students did not note any above-average difficulty in the material of this class; however, many frequented office hours and several mentioned the importance of keeping up with reading.

Chemistry 101 is an introduction to the principles of Chemistry for students with some basic knowledge of Chemistry and Calculus, focusing on understanding chemical reactions at the atomic and molecular level. Enrollment in this section was for engineers only.

The majority of the students taking this course described it as both “interesting” and “rewarding.” Students were pleased that the content focused on topics both “relevant to engineers” and abstract concepts.

The class was dually taught by Professors Pietrovito and Davies. Students agreed that Professor Pietrovito exhibited a "wide range of knowledge," and found him to be highly accessible. However, they also felt that he overcomplicated his lectures, "explaining on a level above the students." Several students also described his lectures as “boring at times.” 

This course presented a challenge to many; one student described it as “difficult in every way,” while another said he would avoid recommending it to “non-masochists.” The class was divided between students that already had a strong background in chemistry from AP/IB courses and those who did not; Students without the credit found the class noticeably harder, while those with stronger backgrounds felt they gained a significantly more “solid” understanding of the material by taking the class. A common complaint was that the exams involved much harder problems than the homework, so students felt unprepared.
